admreg: East Asia and Pacific,East Asia and Pacific

abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Health Development Project (PHDP) in
            the Republic of the Philippines. The Philippines Health
            Development Project (PHDP) was the Bank's first
            comprehensive effort to support the Department of Health
            (DOH) in the Philippines, covering the key areas of disease
            control, health services delivery at the field level and
            capacity building of the DOH. After two population projects
            that performed poorly, PHDP was designed with full
            government ownership and a clear mandate for the DOH. Bank
            performance was highly satisfactory during the preparation
            phase and the borrowers performance and participation in
            project preparation was excellent. Project implementation
            was less satisfactory, however overall outcome of the
            project may be rated as satisfactory since most of the
            objectives were reached at least to some degree. The major
            lesson to be learned from this project is the need to be
            more aware of the political milieu, including monitoring of
            possible legislative actions and other developing scenarios,
            while planning and implementing projects. There should be
            strong linkages between the various components of projects.
            Institutional development components should include a good
            analysis of existing constraints, well specified plans to
            achieve objectives and clear monitoring indicators.
            Streamlining of drugs and equipment procurement and
            distribution, including possible decentralization of
            procurement, particularly of drugs and medical supplies,
            must be assured before any major public health commitment is
            made. Vehicles are often not essential to project success
            and their purchase should be minimized in future projects,
            except where the need can be specifically documented. The
            Bank should budget adequate resources for supervision. While
            multiple task missions may be cost-effective, particular
            care should be taken to ensure that all tasks, in
            particular, project supervision tasks, receive due
            attention. Several donors concurrently support governments
            for activities to achieve certain outcomes and such efforts
            in the future should bring together major stakeholders in
            the planning and design stage to agree on collaborative implementation.
